Posts.Content: Further things you can do that are test towards defining if you might have PCa without the invasive biopsies first: Blood tests there are markers that onco-doc can look for: pyrilinks, pap and some others (not totally definitive however) fPsa testing: it is a different type of Psa test that measures what is called 'unbound' prostate specific antigens (conceptually- floaters or such in your mind). They give parameters in percentages of unbound Psa antigens and it is useful towards defining am I a high risk for having PCa already or low risk (the lower the percentage of unbound fPsa the greater the chance you have Pca). Example: fPsa of 10% vs. fPsa of 40% or higher...the group in the 40% high less likely to have PCa. If you are found with 10-20% fPsa very likely some PCa exists. (again not totally definitive) Special urine testing that is somewhat unknown and available through some uro-docs, that is said to be more accurate at assessing if you have PCa that the Psa testings. You can google Bostwick laboratories or google for PCa urine testings. Then read about it, for some people it would be worth the cost prior to biopsy considerations. Realize that nothing with PCa is 100%-I could point out exceptions on everything, including biopsies, pathology, scanning etc. Only because I took time to look at this over the years. Knowledge is your advocate in cancers, you have to fight it the docs don't, they are not all experts in case you believed such, I have seen may mistakes, errors, and malpractice even in PCa. Truth is worth finding for your journey in this.
Posts.Title: Elevated PSA followed by return to normal: what to do?

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA followed by return to normal: what to do?

Posts.Content: It is good to add something to the arsenal in therapies, however this is said to cost $5000 per month, go figure another low money maker for the drug companies. It has comparisons to the way Ketoconazole works, maybe is more effective and known to be more potent supposedly (written about prior). Now Keto you can buy for a low as $130 for 200 mg and 100 count from www.northerndrugstore.com with an Rx in USA dollars (Canada, they send it to you also). You can do high dose keto or lower dose keto, usually docs have you take prednisone along with it (saftey type thing). Still alot cheaper than this FDA approved drug. Do you think anyone in the U.S. will come out with a low priced drug for PCa, via FDA that is useful and cheap for us????? I can see hospitals endorsing this asap...they don't usually even consider using Keto on patients, but independent docs do so and with results in many patients. The Jungle of PCa...the beat goes on and on. I hate to be cynical vs. clinical (LOL) but we get cashed in on plenty in this country and elsewhere. Must be the newer Hypo Oath that is the problem. (LOL)
Posts.Signature: "Youth is wasted on the Young"-W.C. Fields

Posts.Title: FDA approves Zytiga (abiraterone) for Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: You probably forgot the email has an underscore within it [email protected] Zytiga may work and likely is better than even H.D. keto useage....we should expose the price to public scrutiny...because they are seemlying screwtinizing the users and insurance companies. (Provenge is setting a higher bar for $$$$). Racela still you have choices to look at and drugs that work on VEGF (angiogenesis), also expensive but revlimid, leukine, see if you can get trials on MDX3100 or ARN 509 (same doc invented both of those). Consider emcty, DES or estradiol infusions (mentioned by Dr. Barken today on Prostate-pointers group thing) There are novel therapies and way outside the box ideas...usually nobody looks at those...I do or will look...looking is free I noticed.

Posts.Title: FDA approves Zytiga (abiraterone) for Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: One guy had DaVinci done and doc did not even remove all of his gland and then tried to cover it up and recommended patient for seeing a good ol boy network radiation doc friend of his, as the patients remedy for a rising psa. Only the patient found out the whole story and was in process of suing this doc, whom probably was new at the DaVinci gig. This must be reassuring to new patients! Another one is a newbie brachy doc whom placed brachy radiation seed into a patients seminal vessical and missing the prostate, it was later fixed. These are your experts??? There are others scenarios out there and of course looking at videos of the surgery you would come to the conclusion how do you know where the good tissue vs. bad tissue starts and stops...see videos...this is not like a car engine with obvious connectable parts that even a layperson can identify. PCa is many times not staged or even diagnosed completely or correctly and doctors make your huge decisions based upon alot of less than science and more on 'feelings'. We feel it is contained...that is mentioned way to often and is close to meaningless rehtoric but sold to many a patient. Patients are generally way to trusting of their docs and believe they are total experts, well in PCa almost nobody is a total expert. No rules, plenty of inconsistencies, plenty of variant types and DNA ploidities on PCa cells and many variables. Homogenous treatments are not your best friend, case by case analysis is much more important for real considerations. If you have a really honest doc, he would probably inform you of it being somewhat of a crapshoot, hipshot, and gamble. Maybe a fair or decent gamble depending upon ones stats, but it should be mentioned as your gamble. Beware of guarantee scenarios, great for making sales, bad for patients whom found failure thereafter and looking at salvage treatments in hind site. Don't believe me analyze patient scenarios on forums like this over a few years time span...you will see it all.
Posts.Title: Serious Side Effects of Davinci Robotic Surgery

Posts.Title: Serious Side Effects of Davinci Robotic Surgery

Posts.Content: Just sharing that my brother whom got diagnosed with a low level (perhaps considered the definition of indolent PCa, parameters as mentioned by Brady Urology-John Hopkins) has done W.W. (surveilance-monitoring) for about 5 yrs. now and does not seem insane. His psa has not moved upwards and even dropped a small amount over this time. It is his choice and he has read up on the issues, has Dr. Strums book A Primer on PCa, of which is an excellent source of overall information. Some people enjoy quality of life while they monitor, even though their uro-doc or whomever naturally recommended immediate treatment as if W.W. somehow is non-existent as a choice. It is a real choice, maybe not an easy choice to stand by and live knowing you have some form of PCa. Leading oncologists are less biased about immediate treatment at having indolent looking stats or even little higher stats. Never easy black and white on PCa issues on any level, everything you can think of is less than definitive, might be incorrect data, could even have false positives (prostascint scans). As Robert Young mentioned years ago....'it is a jungle'. (his website: www.phoenix5.org)
Posts.Title: Active Surveillance in Younger Men?

Posts.Content: Travelingman- Is this a Bob Seger name or what? (well one of his songs...good screen name). All choices and treatments or non-treatments have their place in PCa scenarios (para-quoted Dr. Strum et al). Hard part is knowing where a patient might fit. No disrepect to you or others whom have been told they got it all or it was contained.....actual truth is maybe or "likely" or could have been. I don't necessarily want to quote Dr. Barken and other stuff, just always question anything on PCa is a good idea. Monitor your psa's and perhaps blood work and other tests done by some onco-docs, post therapies could be in ones best interests.
Posts.Title: Active Surveillance in Younger Men?

Posts.Content: LHRH (ADT), standard hormone blockage drugs: Lupron, Zoladex, Viadur, Trelstar, ELigard, Abarelix, Buserelin, Nafarelin, Acetate, Degarelix (new and non-flare LHRH) The anti-androgens: casodex, eulexin, niladron (can be effective also in sequencing and getting responses) (5-alpha reductase- blockers of DHT): avodart, proscar Estrogenic drugs: DES (man made estrogen-no patents), estradiol patches (Vivelle, Climara etc.), emcyt (estramusine), PC Spes, Honvan, estradurin, estraderm patch, stilphosterol (Newer drugs some in trials still): Xinlay, Taraceva, Gleevec, Prostvac-VF, Astrasentan, Ertinolib, Vitaxin, ZD4054, Provenge, Ixabepilone, Gvac, Velcade, Calcitriol, Iressa, KOS-862, Satraplatin, Gemzar Abiraterone acetate (phase III-looks promising), Alpharadin, Apatone, Cox-2 inhibitors and NSAIDS, sulindac, exisulind, IMC-A12, Ixempra, epothilone, MDV3100(super casodex), Noscapine, phenoxodiol, quadramet, valproic acid, provenge (vaccines), carboplatin ketoconazole(2nd line hormone drug use), nizoral Chemo or chemotherics: taxotere, taxol, taxane, 5-fu, adriamycin, novantrone, velban, navelbine, etoposide, mitomycin-C, tamoxiphen, mitoxantrone (Radioactive drugs)- strontium, samarium (Immunotherapies)- dendritic cells, monoclonal antibodies (steroids used): decadron, hexdrol, hydrocortisone, prednisone (prolactin inhibitors): dostinex, bromocriptine (selective blocker of adrenal androgens) cytadren (other stuff) megace, thalidomide(dangerous), revlamid, cytoxan, luekine, dexamethasone predisone, triamcinolone, aminoglutethimide, sunitinib, aptosyn This is not necessarily all possible drugs used within the war on PCa, this is why onco-docs are needed, to figure out which, when, how much, the benefits, risks, rewards, side effects, pricing, etc. There are some newer drugs coming (listed above)that appear to be beneficial, some are supposed to be here between now and 2010 for making FDA approval, it is being said. -I'm tired of thinking of all these drugs, but it is warfare on PCa and patients are looking for answers. This is most of the related arsenal drugs used in one way or another on PCa. Alot of angles to fight this disease, once you are in the realm of post treatment (surgery, radiation, cryo, hifu etc.) and you fail the definition of cure psa levels, you might start thinking about a PCa onco-doc and these drugs to combat such. (of course you may have chosen a salvage treatment prior to the drug route or used the drugs in combo with a treatment or salvage). Bolla study shows decent results for combo of ADT hormone therapy prior and during and short time after radiations. Chemo therapies are numerous when used with combo drugs attacted with them, there is web information on alot of those protocols. I am not endorsing chemo treatments, but it is another choice in the PCa world. Dx-2002 I did (radiations) & ADT3 combo for 2 yrs.-Lupron+casodex+proscar, switched to DES-1mg shed myself of all those side effects and even better control, did well enough went of all drugs for 2 yrs., psa went up to 1.46 in Nov-2008 so resumed DES and psa now at .36 so far) Lots of choices to consider out there, the uro-docs do not know of or don't use hardly any of these other than LHRH and the casodex type drugs. Degarelix is new FDA approved- LHRH and does not give 'flare' at first as does the other LHRH, high stats people do not need any flare. It can be handled anyway by taking casodex and its equals 12-14 days prior to getting LHRH in your body (fyi). -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Post Edited (zufus) : 2/14/2009 3:28:54 AM (GMT-7)
Posts.Title: Drugs used in PCa~warfare~some are new~onco-docs use such

Posts.Content: Yes to both of those items you mentioned, I cannot give specifics but those might be useful or to become useful (like) measles. As crazy as measles sounds it is maybe comparable strategy to the concept of using Provenge (a vaccines item). There could be a whole future to treating PCa in the vaccines area and in the manipulation of the cell receptors or at the stem cells too. Plants do have plant like estrogens, and estrogenic effects are super on PCa in general as to causing direct apoptosis (kills cells-PCa) not just making them dormant. There is a very interesting article (200 from Nature Publishing Group- Prostate Cancer & Prostate Diseases (200 11, 6-12 (1365-7852/08 $30) my onco-doc has this publication service apparently. Review: Soy isoflavone genistein in the prevention and treatment of prostate cancer (Dept. of Urology~University Hosp.~Bonn Germany) The concept of this document is this: these herbs which are generic and non-prescription could end up being used as a protocol for PCa and with decent results. The hard part is getting the doseage levels needed into a form that will be useable for patients, it is being looked at now. The players in this are: Genistein (comes from soy beans) and acts like a plant type of estrogen (safe) & then combined with Milkthistle which is 'Silymarin'. So Genistein + Silymarin (but in correct doseage levels), suggested you do not do this on your own or if you do understand the levels needed within this article, especially if you are on certain drug therapies currently, unknown if side effects would prevail. Soy products are useful in general and good to add into your diet if you wish to anyway. Silymarin is also used to promote good liver function, you can take it separately and should be useful to people. In general for foods: lycopene (tomatoes), bright colored fruits (anti-oxidants found), broccoli, cauliflower, watermelon, berries and even red wine, and dark chocolate, certain teas...all useful in helping to prevent cancers or assist in fighting cancers (local study showed patients got longer psa stabilization and even in the hrcpa group too(for some weeks to months), compared to control group without using like lycopene, carrotenoids and such. So there is some value in them.
Posts.Title: Drugs used in PCa~warfare~some are new~onco-docs use such
